author: sfgate.com
title: Daily Briefing, Oct. 25
text:
If you missed it ... 
In a week when Oprah threw her financial weight around, when YouTube planned to make some green with Red and when the only flying DeLoreans were fictional, we also saw:
• Facebook updated its app to try to be less of a battery drain on iPhones , addressing such techie items as CPU spin. As the company’s Ari Grant posted , “A CPU spin is like a child in a car asking, ‘Are we there yet? Are we there yet? Are we there yet?’ with the question not resulting in any progress to reaching the destination. This repeated processing causes our app to use more battery than intended.”
•Runners can now use a popular fitness app on their Apple Watch without having to lug their iPhone around with it. What a concept. As VentureBeat reported , Runkeeper updated its app so you can still see things like heart rate, time, distance and pace. Without the phone, there is no GPS, but other measurements help Runkeeper figure out how far you’re running.
•A story on Realtor.com suggested that some San Francisco renters might be able to save more than $1,000 by renting a place in Las Vegas and commuting. The story cited a Reddit post , which bases the assumptions on you working a four-day week, averaging $70 round-trip airfare and having the self-control not to attack any passengers who try to recline their seats. (OK, the last part may just be implied.)
The Daily Briefing is compiled from San Francisco Chronicle staff and news services. See more items and links at www.sfgate.com . Twitter: @techchronicle
